m.DESC: Number of edges attached from new nodes to existing nodes

Barabasi-Albert.DESC:
The <ansired>Barabasi-Albert</ansired> (BA) model is an algorithm for generating undirected
random scale-free networks using a preferential attachment mechanism.
PROP: The total number of edges is: <ansired>m</ansired>(<ansired>n</ansired>-<ansired>m</ansired>)

m1.DESC: Number of nodes in each of the two complete subgraphs

m2.DESC: Number of nodes in the path connecting the two complete subgraphs

Barbell.DESC:
A <ansired>barbell</ansired> graph is an undirected graph composed of two complete graphs,
each with <ansired>m1</ansired> nodes, connected by a path of <ansired>m2</ansired> nodes.
PROP: The total number of nodes is: 2<ansired>m1</ansired> + <ansired>m2</ansired>
The total number of edges is: <ansired>m1</ansired>(<ansired>m1</ansired>-1) + <ansired>m2</ansired> + 1

Complete.DESC:
A <ansired>complete</ansired> graph is a simple undirected graph in which every
pair of distinct vertices is connected by a unique edge.
PROP: The total number of edges is: <ansired>n</ansired> choose 2 = <ansired>n</ansired>(<ansired>n</ansired>-1)/2
The degree of every node (and thus also the average degree) is: <ansired>n</ansired>-1

Cycle.DESC:
A <ansired>cycle</ansired> graph is an undirected graph that consists of a single cycle.
In other words, the vertices are connected in a closed chain.
PROP: When <ansired>n</ansired> > 2, the number of edges is: <ansired>n</ansired>

Empty.DESC:
An <ansired>empty</ansired> graph is a graph that does not have any edges.

Note that you very likely do not want to use this for epidemic simulations
(as there will not be any edges across which the pathogen can transmit).
